misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Confusing independent if-statements with mutually exclusive else-if chain
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that writing several plain if statements one after another, each testing a different grade range, will result in only one of them executing—specifically, the first one whose condition is true. They implicitly expect Java to stop checking later conditions once an earlier condition has been satisfied, as if they had written an if–else-if–else chain.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, each if statement is evaluated independently. The runtime does not remember that a previous if was true and automatically skip later ifs; it simply evaluates each condition in order and executes the body for every condition that is true. To make the grade categories mutually exclusive, the conditions must either (a) be written so they cannot overlap (e.g., 90–100, 80–89, etc.), or (b) be structured as an if–else-if–else chain so that once one condition is true, the following ones are not even tested. In the student's code, a grade of 95 satisfies all of the conditions grade_value >= 90, >= 80, >= 70, and >= 60, so all their corresponding print statements will run, producing multiple letter grades instead of only 'A'. The student's mental model incorrectly assumes short-circuiting between separate if statements rather than understanding that only else-if/else provide that mutual exclusivity.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: for many inputs the program prints multiple letter grades instead of exactly one (e.g., grade 95 prints A, B, C, and D on separate lines; grade 85 prints B, C, and D).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that a sequence of independent 'if' statements, ordered from the strictest condition (highest grade) to the least strict condition (lowest grade), will automatically behave like an 'if-else if' ladder. They assume that if a condition is met (e.g., grade >= 80), the program will implicitly skip checking all subsequent, less restrictive conditions, ensuring only one path is executed.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, every stand-alone 'if' statement is tested independently. When a grade (e.g., 85) is input, it satisfies all the remaining conditions (85 >= 80, 85 >= 70, 85 >= 60), causing the code to print B, C, AND D. To ensure mutual exclusivity and print only the highest applicable grade, the student must use 'else if' to chain the conditions, or explicitly check for the upper bound (e.g., grade >= 80 && grade < 90).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (Multiple letter grades are printed when only one is expected).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Independent If Statements Not Mutually Exclusive
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that by writing sequential if statements to check grade ranges, only one grade letter will be printed because they are checking in a logical order. They expect the program to stop after finding a match, or they don't realize that a single value can satisfy multiple independent conditions.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, each if statement executes independently. There is no automatic mutual exclusivity between if statements. A grade of 85 satisfies ALL conditions: >= 90 (false), >= 80 (true), >= 70 (true), >= 60 (true), < 60 (false). The student needed to use if-else if statements to ensure only one branch executes. Without else, all true conditions execute their blocks sequentially.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Multiple letter grades are printed for a single input grade. For input 85, the program prints 'Letter grade: B', 'Letter grade: C', and 'Letter grade: D' instead of just 'Letter grade: B'.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Assuming separate if statements are mutually exclusive
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once one of these grade conditions is true and its body executes (e.g., printing "Letter grade: B" for 85), the later if statements for lower thresholds (>= 70, >= 60, < 60) will automatically be skipped, as if the ifs were linked in an if-else-if chain. They are mentally treating each range as exclusive by intent, and assuming Java enforces that exclusivity without needing explicit else or else-if.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, each if statement is evaluated independently unless it is explicitly connected with else or else-if. The conditions here overlap: a value like 85 satisfies >= 80, >= 70, and >= 60, and a value like 95 satisfies >= 90, >= 80, >= 70, and >= 60. Because the student used multiple standalone if statements rather than an if/else-if/else chain, the runtime checks every condition in order and executes every body whose condition is true. This produces multiple letter-grade outputs for a single numeric grade, which contradicts the intended one-to-one mapping. The mental model error is thinking that the control flow automatically stops checking later conditions once one condition has been true, even when only plain if statements are used.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: for some inputs (e.g., 85 or 95), the program prints multiple letter grades instead of exactly one.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when a series of if statements describes mutually exclusive conditions (like grade ranges), the execution flow will automatically cease searching or evaluating subsequent conditions once a true condition is met and an output is generated. They treat independent if statements (L9, L12, L15, L18) as if they are chained together using else if logic.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, standard if statements are evaluated entirely independently. If an input grade of 85 satisfies (grade_value >= 80) it prints 'B', but execution continues regardless, and since 85 also satisfies (grade_value >= 70) and (grade_value >= 60), it subsequently prints 'C' and 'D'. To enforce mutual exclusivity and stop execution after the first true condition is found (which is necessary for tiered grading logic), the student must use else if structures.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: For any grade 80 and above, multiple letters are printed (e.g., 85 prints B, C, D; 95 prints A, B, C, D).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that each if statement checks a condition independently and that checking conditions like >= 80, >= 70, >= 60 will result in only the appropriate grade being printed. They do not realize that all three conditions can be true simultaneously, causing multiple print statements to execute.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student confuses independent if statements with mutually exclusive if-else if chains. In Java, each if statement is evaluated independently in sequence. When grade_value is 85, it satisfies grade_value >= 80 (true), grade_value >= 70 (true), and grade_value >= 60 (true). Since these are separate if statements (not if-else if), all three blocks execute. The student appears to believe that once a condition is satisfied, subsequent conditions won't be checked or that the conditions are mutually exclusive.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - multiple letter grades are printed instead of a single letter grade. For input 85, the program outputs 'B', 'C', and 'D' instead of just 'B'.
